description: From Middle English carpe (late 14th century), via Old French carpe from a surmised Vulgar Latin *carpa (which is also the source of Italian carpa). The word is of Germanic origin, cognate with Old High German karpho. An East Germanic origin (unrecorded Gothic *karpa) has been proposed, as the fish was introduced from the Danube.

entries.meaning: Any of various freshwater fish of the family Cyprinidae, especially the common carp, Cyprinus carpio.

description: From Old Norse karpa (“to boast, brag”), karp (“bragging”); meaning later changed to "find fault with, carp at" due to influence of Latin carpō.

verbs.description: carp (third-person singular simple present carps, present participle carping, simple past and past participle carped)

entries.meaning: To complain about a fault; to harp on.
(obsolete, transitive) To find fault with; to censure.
examples: and with your good countenance protect against the malice of evil mouths, which are always wide open to carp at and misconstrue my simple meaning
